PELICAN MEAL/PACKET "PICK UP" INFORMATION
WEDNESDAYS 9:00-11:00
For all families who told us they prefer to "pick up at school" option.

If you chose "bus" - the bus department will be reaching out to you with times and locations.

We have been asked to ensure that we are practicing social distancing. Therefore, we are asking parents who...

ARE DRIVING...(see attached (super fancy) picture)
*Use Hanks St. (back of school)
*Stay in car and circle around the staff parking lot
*Stop at playground fence, stay in car, and a school employee will ask who student(s) are/ how many kids for meals
*Tables will be in the parking lot where school employee will set food/packet , employee will back away
*Parent will get out of the car when employee backs away, grab box, and drive off. :)

ARE WALKING ...
You will be entering via the playground. There will be a table at the top of the stairs with the same process. We will have cones out to ensure social distancing.

This is a big undertaking - please be patient with us as we bob and weave our way through this!

Be Safe. Mrs. McCabe

CONTINUING ED MEANS BETTER STUDENT SUPPORT

About 150 staff attended a full-day training Feb. 9 on working with students affected by trauma or autism. Peter Buckley, a former Jackson County legislator now working with Southern Oregon Success, presented on supporting and building resilience in trauma-affected students. Rowan Hill-Walko, an autism spectrum disorders specialist from Southern Oregon Education Service District, presented The Role of the Paraprofessional and Autism 101. In addition to 90-100 district paraprofessionals, the event drew transportation and food service staff who interact with all student populations. Monthly, one-hour professional development trainings for district paraprofessionals are planned for Professional Learning Community time (Wednesday “late start” time) in March, April and May.

NEWS RELEASE

History of Klamath Union

The history of Klamath Union High School will be presented in a program at 6:30 p.m. Friday, Nov. 29, in the school’s cafeteria.

The presentation by the Klamath County Museum will cover previous use of the building location, construction and expansion of the school, and some of the lighter sides of the school’s history.

“The recent opening of the renovated school, cafeteria and theater mark a major milestone in the proud history of the school,” said museum manager Todd Kepple. “We hope this program gives people a chance to reminisce about the school, and perhaps help us fill in some gaps in our records.”

Klamath Union High School opened in 1928. Major additions to the school included a gymnasium in 1938 and a south wing in 1958. A grand opening of the recently renovated school was held last month.

For more information contact the museum at (541) 882-1000.

Parents of soon-to-be kindergarten students. Wanted to share some advice I read recently.

Practice eating “school lunch” with your kiddo. Make sure they can open everything you send with them or things like milk containers if they will be eating a school lunch. Talk about not putting food directly on the table in the lunchroom and let them know that a cafeteria can be noisy. Set a timer for 20 minutes and talk about how they may not finish eating and that’s ok. Practice packing everything back up and talk about what is trash and what should come back home in their lunch box. If you get a chance, go to your child's school and ask if you can walk them through the cafeteria. Kindergarten lunch is a big adjustment; your child will feel more comfortable and their teacher will be appreciative if you have prepared them for this experience!

From Destination Imagination coordinator, Bill Patterson: The Ponderosa Team finished 13th in their engineering challenge out of over 70 participants from around the world.

They rocked in the Technical challenge and finished 5th (out of over 70 teams). They just missed 3rd and a trip to the stage. The team that finished ahead of them were China, Colorado, Indiana and Ontario Canada.

The appraisers were amazed at both their drone and folding van. Both of those things made the closing ceremony video.

One of the best things happened as we were leaving. Another team came up to them and said they were their inspiration for doing DI. They told the kids that they proved Oregon could compete and do well at Globals even though the state was small. I hear our kids have become the premiere team in the state and lots of younger kids look up to them. Pretty good for little old Klamath Falls.
